headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the CSRA Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Stuart Davis, Vice President of Investor R
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the CSRA Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Stuart Davis, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategy. Please go ahead.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Welcome, everyone, to today's quarterly earnings conference call. Larry Prior, our CEO and Dave Keffer, our CFO, are here to discuss our financial results, business momentum and forward outlook. Today's call is being webcast on the Investor Re
componenttext:
Thank you Welcome, everyone, to today's quarterly earnings conference call. Larry Prior, our CEO and Dave Keffer, our CFO, are here to discuss our financial results, business momentum and forward outlook. 
Today's call is being webcast on the Investor Relations portion of our website, where you'll also find the earnings release and supplemental financial presentation slides that we'll be using in today's call. 
The information contained in the earnings release and supplemental financial presentation is fundamentally unaudited at this time. 
Turning to Slide 2 of the presentation, please note that during this call, we will make forward-looking statements that are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from anticipated results. 
For a full discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please refer to our SEC filings, including our Form 10-Q from February and our Form 10-K, which we will file later this week. 
In addition, these statement represents our views as of today and subsequent events may cause our views to change. We may elect to update the forward-looking statements at some point in the future, but we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so. 
Finally, as shown on Slide 3, we will discuss some non-GAAP financial measures and other metrics, which we believe provide useful information for investors. Unless specifically called out, all statements on the call reference pro forma adjusted figures. 
The slide deck for today's call includes an explanation of those adjustments and other reconciliations of the figures to the most comparable GAAP measures. 
At this time, it's my pleasure to turn the call over to Larry, who will begin on Slide 4.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stuart. Good afternoon, everybody. We're pleased to report another strong quarter of profitability, cash flow and business development performance. With about 6 months as a public company under our belts, merger integration is mostly behind us, an
componenttext:
Thanks, Stuart. Good afternoon, everybody. We're pleased to report another strong quarter of profitability, cash flow and business development performance. With about 6 months as a public company under our belts, merger integration is mostly behind us, and we've dramatically exceeded our cost synergy targets. 
We're now solidly focused on execution and our Q4 results demonstrate the strength of our position in the market. 
Since our last call, we've spent time on the road introducing the company to investors and we've gained additional research coverage, so we'll trim the commentary a bit to leave plenty of time for your questions. 
As I review our performance, 3 key points standout: first, our Q4 profit and cash flow, we're well ahead of our expectations, bolstering the investment thesis that we've laid out previously; second, our guidance for FY '17 demonstrates our relentless focus on efficiency to drive earnings, while lingering revenue headwinds abate; and third, our long-term growth model is very much intact. 
Now I'll explore each of these thoughts in a little bit more detail. First, on the quarterly results. Revenue and earnings were both up sequentially and all of our key metrics were within or above the guidance that we gave on last call. 
The number one question we get from investors is, can you sustain your margins and today's results provide additional evidence that the answer is yes. Our EBITDA margin of 17.4% leads the industry. The compatibility of our 2 legacy companies, compatibility and values like honesty and service, compatibility with our cultural affinity where the best idea wins, compatibility with a commitment to mission next-Gen IT and cost control, this compatibility has allowed us to move quickly and integration and as we come together, we've identified additional ways to operate more efficiently. 
Our expanded base of fixed-price contracts incentivizes us to drive down cost continually and responsibly. Our efficiencies create a near-term revenue headwind, but are highly accretive to earnings. 
During the quarter, we also posted strong bookings, which build the foundation for future revenue growth. 
Our book-to-bill of 1.0x for the quarter and 1.3x for the year demonstrates that we can compete fiercely in the federal IT marketplace. Almost half of the bookings in the quarter were new business, including our $252 million tenure award with the Security and Exchange Commission. 
In addition, we generated excellent free cash flow in the quarter and stuck to our balanced capital allocation model. Free cash flow was $167 million, which is double our net income and a result of our dedication to cash collections and cash management. 
We paid down significant debt, paid a quarterly dividend and repurchased our shares just as we said that we do when we approach the public market for the first time. 
Second, on the guidance for FY '17. We'll continue to carefully manage our margins to generate earnings growth. With pension income comparable to Q3 and Q4, our adjusted EBITDA range would be $886 million to $921 million and adjusted EPS would be $0.97 million to $2.10 million. 
This equates to year-over-year EPS growth of 4% at the midpoint and 7% at the high-end of the range. Dave  will update in just a minute the changes to the pension income that will modify these numbers. 
We expect revenue of $5 billion to $5.2 billion. At the midpoint, revenue would be 2% lower than in FY '16. More than half of the revenue reduction comes from the impact of our aggressive cost reductions on cost reimbursable contracts. 
This cost discipline is part of our DNA and we'll drive earnings in cash for our shareholders, as shown by the earnings growth in our FY '17 guidance. 
Within the last month, we had a few of our new wins protested, and we do not know when these will be completed. Therefore, we've taken them out of our guidance. Our new wins over the last year have been strong, and we're confident that the book-to-bill ratios above 1 will lead to growth, which brings me to my third point on our long-term model. We're committed to 2% to 3% revenue growth and 8% to 10% EPS growth annually over the long term. 
Our win rates and win volumes are testament to the relevance and competitiveness of our offerings. 
Our backlog is now $15.1 billion, which is about 3x annual revenue. Backlog is up 5% year-over-year and ultimately, revenue will grow in line with backlog. 
We have $6 billion in submitted proposals of waiting decisions, and we expect to submit more than $10 billion of proposals in the first half of the year. 
More broadly, our market is slowly returning to growth, and our customers are increasingly adopting next-generation IT. These trends give us further confidence in the direction we're taking the business as we aim to execute at the intersection of growing vertical markets and compelling technology offerings. 
In the process, you could rely on this management team to continue to take aggressive cost actions and freeing up the right resources to prudently invest in growth. 
Now Dave will provide a bit more detail on the financial results and our forward outlook.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry, and good afternoon, everyone. I share Larry's view that fourth quarter results were very strong. We maintained our focus on margins and cash collections, while solidifying our team and our operations. Turning to Slide 5 are primarily addr
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry, and good afternoon, everyone. I share Larry's view that fourth quarter results were very strong. We maintained our focus on margins and cash collections, while solidifying our team and our operations. 
Turning to Slide 5 are primarily address pro forma and adjusted results. For prior periods, our pro forma results assumed CSC spin and SRA merger that already occurred and for all periods, we exclude cost directly associated with either the spin or merger transactions or the ongoing integration. 
We believe pro forma adjusted figures provide an important baseline for comparing the past and future performance. Our press release provides all appropriate reconciliations from pro forma adjusted results to GAAP results. 
Revenue for the fourth quarter was $1.29 billion, up 1.5% sequentially and down 4.4% from $1.35 billion of pro forma revenue in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2015. 
The uptick in revenue compared to last quarter resulted from the normal pattern of lower leave taking  in our fourth quarter than in our third. 
On a pro forma basis, our Civil segment, which includes health, homeland security and other federal civilian agencies, was down 1% year-over-year. our Defense and Intelligence segment was down 8% year-over-year. One source of this decline was at Army Logistics Modernization Program, which is transitioning to a maintenance phase after a very successful large-scale software deployment. 
In addition, lower material purchases on Navy contracts, the sale of our business and the wind down of Army OCO work outweigh the ramp up of valuable new intelligence programs. Contract mix remained a key driver of profitability in Q4, as our mix continued its trend towards fixed price. 
As a percentage of total revenue, our contracts in the quarter were 45% fixed price, 21% time and materials and 35% cost-plus. 
Keying in on the income adjustments. We incurred a GAAP noncash expense of $203 million from the annual mark-to-market process for our pension programs, which is split about 97% in cost of services and 3% in SG&A. 
The noncash expense was a result of the continued low interest rate environment and the return on plan assets running below our long-term assumption. 
The mark-to-market remeasurement is part of our standard year-end process. We're not expecting another remeasurement gain or loss until next Q4. We also incurred merger and integration costs of $27 million in the quarter. 
With that in mind, you can really see the impact of our synergy savings. Pro forma SG&A was $44 million in the quarter compared to $62 million in Q3, and we expected to continue to decline in FY '17. 
More than half of the cost synergies are in cost of services. So in total, we're already generating savings of over $150 million on an annual run rate basis. 
We make tough choices quickly, which have enabled us to grow earnings, invest in growth and move forward as a team. 
As a result of these savings, adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $225 million, near the high-end of our guidance. Adjusted EBITDA was up 8% from the same period a year ago, as EBITDA margin increased from 15.5% to 17.4%. 
Fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA excludes $2 million of stock-based compensation expense and includes $28 million of net pension related income. 
Pro forma depreciation and amortization expense was $49 million, which excludes the $16 million GAAP intangibles amortization expense associated with SRAs funded contract backlog. 
Interest expense was $29 million in the quarter. 
Late in Q4, we hedged about half of our term loan debt. So our interest expense will be approximately $6 million higher in FY '17, but we'll have greater certainty and stability if interest rates rise from their historically low levels. 
Our comparability across periods, pro forma earnings per share are calculated assuming an effective tax rate of 39%, the company's estimated long-term rate. Pro forma adjusted diluted earnings per share for the quarter were $0.50, above the high-end of the guidance that we provided last call. 
EPS for the quarter was up 32% from $0.38 in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015 and up 4% from last quarter. 
Diluted share count for the quarter was $164 million. The pro forma metrics for the fiscal year show the same basic patterns with the same underlying drivers, as the quarterly results. Revenue was $5.2 billion, which was down 4.5% from $5.4 billion in fiscal year 2015. Adjusted EBITDA was $894 million, which was up 3.4% from $865 million in fiscal year 2015, as adjusted EBITDA margins increased from 15.9% to 17.2%. 
Adjusted diluted earnings per share for the fiscal year were $1.96, which was up 14% from $1.72 in fiscal year 2015. 
Turning to Slide 6. We believe free cash flow should ultimately drive valuation. And it's an important metric in setting incentive compensation. 
Free cash flow for the quarter was $167 million or 2.1x adjusted net income, well beyond our normal model of a little better than net income, as a result of sequential working capital improvements. 
During the quarter, the company deployed $117 million to pay down debt, $13 million to repurchase shares and $16 million in dividends, consistent with our balance capital deployment approach. 
Day sales outstanding were 52 days as of the quarter end, an improvement of 12 days from the end of the prior fiscal year and 3 days sequentially. 
Our ongoing program to sell our receivables lower DSO by about 13 days. Through this program, we're able to enhance our liquidity in a very reasonable cost because of the positive relationships that we have with our creditworthy government customers. 
As of April 1, 2016, the company had $130 million in cash and cash equivalents on the balance sheet. 
On the debt side, we had $50 million of drawn revolver, $2.8 billion of term loan debt and $151 million of capital leases at quarter end. 
We expect to make at least another $40 million in debt payments in the first quarter of FY '17, consistent with our term loan agreements. Our steady cash flows and $650 million of undrawn revolver capacity provide substantial liquidity and flexibility to manage the business, pay down debt, return cash to shareholders and make accretive acquisitions. 
Turning to our forward guidance on Slide 7. We project that our FY 2017 revenue will be between $5 billion and $5.2 billion, which equates to year-over-year pro forma revenue growth rate range of minus 4% to flat, indicating progress from the rate of decline we experienced in FY '16. 
We project that our adjusted EBITDA will be between $870 million and $905 million. And our adjusted diluted earnings per share will be between $1.91 and $2.04. 
This earnings guidance includes a reduction in projected noncash pension income of $16 million. As Larry noted, absent this change, guidance would have been $886 million to $921 million for EBITDA and $1.97 to $2.10 for EPS. 
Finally, we're introducing free cash flow guidance of between $300 million and $350 million. At its midpoint, this would be slightly above our expectation for adjusted net income. 
Now let me provide a little more color on some of the individual metrics, starting with revenue. We told investors that in a typical year, we'll have 5% to 10% of our business that we need to replace. 
In FY '17, a few contract headwinds push us slightly above that range, in addition to the wind down of our Army Logistics Modernization Program we'll face tough compares on a few large contracts that had outstanding performance last year and will return to more normal levels this year. 
Our 3 largest movers, LMP, a loss DHS recompete and the New York Health Insurance Exchange contract, together decreased overall revenue by about 4%. This was part of the natural churn of our business. 
On top of the contract headwinds, the effective cost take out on our cost plus contracts reduces revenue by more than a point as well. 
As for tailwinds, we have had outstanding contract award activity over the past year. Recent new business awards, including those of the SEC, VA, Department of Justice and Key Intelligence Agencies should add about 5% to our FY '17 revenue. 
2 other new business awards that would have added another 1% to 2% were reversed on protest within the past month. 
In total, maintaining our strong level of new business wins should get us to the midpoint of our range, and we could move higher or lower based on better win performance for unexpected delays. 
On the earnings side, we're guiding to an EBITDA margin of about 17.5%, higher than our original target from the spin of 16% to 17%. We have some tough year-over-year compares with contract profitability and interest expense hedges will cost about $6 million in FY '17, but we'll be able to sustain the excellent margins we posted. 
Over the last 2 quarters given higher-than-expected synergy execution and our usual strength in contract profitability. Our guidance for the fiscal year includes a pension income forecast of $96 million based on the fourth quarter pension remeasurement. 
For the last half of FY '16, pension income was running at an annual rate of $112 million. Thus the change in pension reduced our EBITDA guidance for the year by $16 million and our EPS guidance by $0.06. 
To give you a picture of how the guidance will track over the fiscal year, many of the contract headwinds we've discussed are present in the first half of the fiscal year. We expect to build from there, as recent and expected new business wins ramp and are reflected in the second half results. 
With that, I'll turn it back to you, Larry, for some additional comments.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and it's good to see adding cash flow as a metric makes you emotional and chokes you up a bit. Before turning your questions, I want to spend a few more moments discussing our return to growth. We recognized that revenue growth is key to t
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and it's good to see adding cash flow as a metric makes you emotional and chokes you up a bit. Before turning your questions, I want to spend a few more moments discussing our return to growth. 
We recognized that revenue growth is key to the long-term success of our business. And our recent business development results are very positive. 
I'm now on Slide 8. A second half of book-to-bill ratio of 1.2x normally our lowest awards quarters is really great news. Looking at the quarter in detail, supports our long-term growth picture. Of our $1.3 billion awards, 48% were for new works and our win rate on new work was 36%, which is well above our long-term target. 
Throughout  the company, we have great examples of building brilliant teams to attack the market, and I'd like to highlight 3 of them from the fourth quarter. First, as I said, we won a new 10-year $252 million contract to reshape and operate the IT infrastructure for the Securities and Exchange Commission. Project Manager, Brian Polk, led the winning team. We developed a compelling organizational change management plan and approach to mitigate the contract and migrate it from staff augmentation to fixed price managed services. We'll be providing next-gen IT support to 6,000 users at SEC headquarters and to 11 regional offices around the country. 
Second, under and energetic team leadership, we submitted our initial proposal, which is the primary recompete of our largest contract groundbreaker. We bid as part of the Eagle Alliance, a joint venture between CSRA and North with heavy participation from our next generation alliance partners. The massive bid submission is only the first of several submissions with an expected award in the spring or summer of calendar 2017. 
Third, we won a $54 million recompete of our stimulation work for the Environmental Protection Agency, with Deb Miller as the Project Manager and Proposal Lead. We're using best-in-class technologies, scientific applications and visualization technologies to develop sophisticated environmental models and simulations to provide insight into environmental issues that are too large to replicate in the real world work, like climate change. 
We want to be at the forefront of complex problems that span across agencies and climate changes is one of them. 
These are just a few examples of the early returns we're generating on growth investments. Still, we've not yet turned to growth, so we've decided as a company to take additional aggressive actions around business development as shown on Slide 9. 
First, we continued our step up in growth investments. As we spun out, we've been submitting about $10 billion annually in new business proposals. 
In the fourth quarter, we submitted about $3 billion of proposals for new awards, and we expect to accelerate that pace and reach $16 billion in new submits in FY '17. 
We've also invested in differentiated technical solutions. And that area, we've just been recognized as one off 3 cloud service providers, the others being Amazon Web Services and Microsoft to meet the rigorous security standards to achieve a fed ramp baseline accreditation. 
Our CIO, Jon deserves a lot of credit here. This is a major accomplishment and security enhancement, and it reassures our customers that CSRA is vigilant in providing highly secure government cloud services. 
This is one of the many signs that our strategy to become the leading partner to the U.S. Government, as it transitions the next-generation IT services is on track. 
Second, we changed our organizational structure and personnel. Working with the board and with Dave, I tuned up our organization to be more efficient and focused on growth. 
The new structure is leaner, with the heavy bias towards customer Going from 6 groups down to 4 has created clear lanes to pursue new work. George who is the driving force behind many of the large technology driven takeaway wins at SRA, has stepped up as CSRA's Chief Growth Officer. In addition, to business development, George will oversee our alliance partnerships and our technical solutions unified go-to-market organization. 
Finally, we come to another first in our life as a public company with our first Annual Meeting of Stockholders of CSRA Inc. to be held on August 9, 2016. 
This annual meeting will be a completely virtual meeting of stockholders, which will be conducted via live webcast. 
As a next-gen company, we're embracing the latest technology to provide expanded access, improved communications and of course, cost savings for our stockholders and the company. 
Operator, we're now ready to take some questions.

componenttext: Yes, so I was waiting for the second question. Yes, absolutely, we're committed to our long-term guidance. We were really good at managing our cost structure, delivering earnings converting to cash. So the foundation of the team is really solid. What we found Gautam is, it takes us time to build that pipeline, build the number of submits and just create that forward momentum that have the new business, replace any of the program erosion that Dave spoke to. We think that momentum that we've built up the new business is really solid and supports our long-term guidance. We wish it was happening today, but it's going to take us several quarters of fighting to continue to win those battles on the competitive landscape to see that growth.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just if you could also maybe provide some context around the recent recompete losses, the DHS one that Dave Dave mentioned, was there any common threat to why you lost those, were those surprising to you? And relatedly, on the New York contract,
componenttext: Okay. And just if you could also maybe provide some context around the recent recompete losses, the DHS one that Dave Dave mentioned, was there any common threat to why you lost those, were those surprising to you? And relatedly, on the New York contract, has that been extended, as you expected it would be, or what is the status there?

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first in terms of the setting the context, I think it's a great question. And really, fundamentally, our book-to-bill has been 1 or higher now for, I think,  5 straight quarters. And anytime, we lose, especially, a recompete, we really want to go to th
componenttext: So first in terms of the setting the context, I think it's a great question. And really, fundamentally, our book-to-bill has been 1 or higher now for, I think,  5 straight quarters. And anytime, we lose, especially, a recompete, we really want to go to the root cause and then see if there is any common themes. And frankly, we got some lessons learned, but they've been one-off as opposed to anything that's systemic. Overall, our recomplete win rate was about 80% for the year in terms of numbers -- I'm sorry, in terms of dollars. And I think like 96% in terms of numbers. And it's a slight downward movement, but it's not precipitous. There were 2, as Dave partially mentioned, recompete losses in the year that drove that 80% number. The first one was the  program at DHS. And clearly. that was a place where the customer wanted to split the program into several smaller contracts that we were in the radius to another large program and other large prime, and we've all got painted as big with the same brush. The awards generally went to smaller companies and my takeaway there is, we've got a really evidence and push our capabilities around next-gen, if we're going to differentiate ourselves as a big prime and really highlight the work we do with Amazon or the work we do with big data analytics get painted with just that SI brush for enterprise work. Web SEM was another one and there, we really think the merger with SRA really would have given us a different set of cards to play with. It was an ERP job and vendor partnerships are just critical, and that's just one of the strengths that legacy CSC brings to the table. SRA just didn't have that ERP experience or that we now have jointly as CSRA. So I think it would be a different outcome if we had been in player earlier.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gautam, you also mentioned, the New York Exchange contract, just a briefly comment on that. We do still expect an extension to take our work well into the future. The nature of the decline, we mentioned, year-over-year from '16 to '17 is more related to t
componenttext: Gautam, you also mentioned, the New York Exchange contract, just a briefly comment on that. We do still expect an extension to take our work well into the future. The nature of the decline, we mentioned, year-over-year from '16 to '17 is more related to the timing of a deployment on the contract it is to any change in our status with that customer. We have a great relationship with them, and '16 results were particularly strong as a result of a very successful deployment.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just 3 closing comments, it was an important question. The bid is still in a protest, and I can't say much about it, but we're proceeding with our protest. I'm happy to report that in Q1, we did win $180 million recompete in our healthcare business fo
componenttext: And just 3 closing comments, it was an important question. The bid is still in a protest, and I can't say much about it, but we're proceeding with our protest. I'm happy to report that in Q1, we did win $180 million recompete in our healthcare business for the congressionally directed medical research And I know George is absolutely focused on making every one of our recompetes blue. We have an enterprise-wide initiative that we're calling taking a fresh look at all of our recompetes and really doubling down on our stands going forward. So thank you for the question.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016

componenttext: Just staying on the revenue turnaround sort of question, you talked about next year large part of the headwinds being in the first half of the year, so should we expect in first quarter revenues to be sequentially down, and do you expect by the end of the year when you look at revenue on a year-over-year basis, you'll turn positive?

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not -- I mean, it's Dave, and I appreciate the question. We're not at this point going to call the quarter in which revenue growth turns positive. What we will say consistent with your question and with our comments at the end of the call is,
componenttext: Well, we're not -- I mean, it's Dave, and I appreciate the question. We're not at this point going to call the quarter in which revenue growth turns positive. What we will say consistent with your question and with our comments at the end of the call is, as we think about the way the fiscal '17 quarters rollout, we do have headwinds in the first half of the year that we expect to offset with new business wins as the year progresses. We're running between 4% and 5% year-over-year declines in each of the last 4 quarters. Our guidance for the coming year at its midpoint is down 2%. So I think what you could possibly expect then is the end of the year is closer to 0% than the beginning of the year is and that's that kind of natural progression of '17. It's not to say that there won't be any quarterly ups and downs throughout, but that's the general trend of it.

componenttext: At this point, cost synergies turned from being merger-related synergies, as we rollout the new organization to being just good cost control of the company going forward. So is there additional opportunity for cost efficiency? Of course, overtime, that's part of the fabric of this company is really strong cost efficiency in $150-plus million that we talked about on the call today is just further evidence of that strength in the company. Look going forward, we'll continue to look for incremental efficiencies every year, but certainly, don't feel like those will continue to scale on the kind of $150 million level. These will be more around the edges going forward.

componenttext: And we do plant this fiscal year -- this is Larry, to continue our investment in Bossier City of Louisiana with our ITC there. Our job of development capability there is added a couple of customers, and we're pretty excited about continuing to invest in time and sweat equity and making that a success for sure.

componenttext: No. It's a great question and first, congratulations to Mike Lowry and Paul Soli and the team over at CSC for really hit the home run that is a true inflection point in the market. Remember the timing talking about closing around March of 2017. So as a company and we've got a lot of time to think about this. For the moment, every day, we team with HP and we compete with HP. So I would expect it to be business as usual for all parties, as they navigate the next 9 months. I know our board is tremendously interested in it and will consider it along with all of the other strategic opportunities that will avail themselves for the market over the next year. Mike, absolutely, through a big rock in the pond, spectacular moment and we'll see how it ripples across our market.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're still seeing slower adoption across government, as they're still cautious, as they make the move. We found, as I shared with the last call with the FAA, where we had won the FAA cloud opportunity and it was moving very conservative pace, where w
componenttext: So you're still seeing slower adoption across government, as they're still cautious, as they make the move. We found, as I shared with the last call with the FAA, where we had won the FAA cloud opportunity and it was moving very conservative pace, where we're very thoughtful about mapping the work flows and what would move appropriately to the cloud. But it in parallel, we've worked into a third blown registry with a sense of urgency over the holidays. So that you still get that kind of contrast in adoption rates, where it's asymptomatic where they're picking it up fast and others where they're being very conservative and thoughtful in their approach. Pricing has been generally okay. But remember, you're using automation instead of people to provide the processing, the storage, the computer and so you get favorable pricing, but at lower revenue levels.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016

componenttext: And you can also see that in each of the last quarter, some of our largest wins have been in the next-gen area. You had the  work that we talked about last time the extension of FAA  cloud work. And the SEC opportunity definitely has a very much of IT as a service kind of flavor. So that bulk of up our business is definitely increasing and the margins can be very good in there. I mean, its ones where the margins will grow over time, as we gain execution credibility there, but margins would be fine in that business.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as you think about across the federal government, there is a rich ongoing in Congress right now, the appropriate use or actually the inappropriate use of LPTA, Low Priced Technically Acceptable. Well, as folks moved to next-gen, they're really go
componenttext: And then as you think about across the federal government, there is a rich ongoing in Congress right now, the appropriate use or actually the inappropriate use of LPTA, Low Priced Technically Acceptable. Well, as folks moved to next-gen, they're really going to as a service and consumption based buying, which is driven by metrics and allows the government substantial savings. So we believe that's the long-term trend, where government will go, but it's vary by agency and the adoption rates won't what we're seeing on the commercial side.

Obviously, that last piece is the most volatile of them even that it's dependent on the specific and strategy copper jennet is in the M&A space. In terms of investments needed  in to -- in terms of reinvestment in the business that's going to be a lower number over time. We typically don't have great capital requirements and around our cloud capabilities, we have a few specific contracts that have some capital requirements, but not necessarily in that space. We don't see that as a major cash need going forward.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a lot of the investment is embedded in programs or part of our growth of the ITC in Bossier City. So for example, we ramped up ramping up a test as a service capability, where we're repurposing work that's done virtually across the nation and get
componenttext: And then a lot of the investment is embedded in programs or part of our growth of the ITC in Bossier City. So for example, we ramped up ramping up a test as a service capability, where we're repurposing work that's done virtually across the nation and getting a center of excellence in Bossier City. Ramping up the Java developers or ramping up exports, a lot of that is hiring to programs and building critical mass for that technical talent that's needed and really to work with our partners. That central to our move to next-gen IT is less direct investment by us as oppose to we bring the customer knowledge they work cooperatively with an Amazon Web Services  to deliver a next-gen service. So we're absolutely relying on our strategic partnerships, and it mitigates to a certain extent the investment that we need to directly do or through acquisition.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I got a few. So in your original sort of presentation, you identified $800 million of incremental revenue opportunity through your proposal pipeline, how you're hitting compare to that target, what's the hit rate? And then also can you talk -- you also ta
componenttext: I got a few. So in your original sort of presentation, you identified $800 million of incremental revenue opportunity through your proposal pipeline, how you're hitting compare to that target, what's the hit rate? And then also can you talk -- you also talked about some long-term sort of trends in your end markets, DoD  growth in low single digits, non-DoD IT growth sort of mid-single digits and then intelligence growth in the high single digits, how are you seeing the actual end markets play out at this stage and are you seeing the growth rates that you had anticipated?

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes,, so I mean, when you listen to the debate currently in Congress the different and authorization bills, you're seeing an overall real increase, but in small percentages in the IT community. So think of real growth of 3% over the long-term. You are sen
componenttext: Yes,, so I mean, when you listen to the debate currently in Congress the different and authorization bills, you're seeing an overall real increase, but in small percentages in the IT community. So think of real growth of 3% over the long-term. You are sensing higher single-digit growth for cyber work and double-digit growth for cloud and data analytics. There is a rich debate right now over the President's proposal to have a $3 billion fund, really focused on legacy repair of IT to improve our cyber posture of the federal government. So I keep a steady eye on how that results, as it works this way across the debate. I think there's a hearing with GSA in the CIOs  of government this week or next week. I know they've been working the hill And what I think it underpins is how important cyber is to the nation and that you got to work the fundamental enterprise IT to do it. So I think the trends are positive. But again, it's a very political environment with a lot of polarization on the Hill and Presidential campaign, I think, unprecedented in the noise level. When you asked about the conversion of revenue, remember the process was to build our pipeline, getting to the $16 billion of annual submits, working through the time line of those being awarded and then converting to revenue. So this is the earnings release of where we're stepping up our new submits by -- I don't know 60% with all of the investment around that. As Stuart said, we'll be frontloading a lot of those submits, and we think the awards in our first half, but remember for every one of those, their average life of 5-year contracts, so you also have to mitigate and think of the funnel of your profitability of win. So we expect in '18 to start to see the real impact of that and affecting us positively in growth. But that's the kind of time time you have to think about it moving from pipeline to submits, to awards to that $800 million run rate.

So we're not there yet, but we're definitely on path.

componenttext: I think what's happened is government went back to work and you saw the acquisition process working, where things are being awarded and then protested and then So I think that's a positive note in the market and should continue, I think, to improve once we get past the Presidential election. So I think being able to differentiate ourselves with our customers where we know their mission, we know their enterprise IT and we can help them with that digital future has helped us in our company in getting those wins.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016

componenttext: What I seen and witnessed is that sometimes, it's hard to get a customer to move to fixed price, but once they have, their's a lot of inertia there. They see a lot of benefits, they like the predictability of it, they like the incentives that it provides and the lower price. And so they tend to stay in fixed price.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the challenge they face in government is if you do ideal real right, if you got great metrics around your IT, it's not a hard to cross that Rubicon and go to a fixed-price delivery model based on performance metrics. And then if you take it 1 step fur
componenttext: And the challenge they face in government is if you do ideal real right, if you got great metrics around your IT, it's not a hard to cross that Rubicon and go to a fixed-price delivery model based on performance metrics. And then if you take it 1 step further and move to the cloud and buy something by the hour or the minute, you're as a service environment and you're doing consumption based buying that is fixed price. So I think inevitably, the federal government will move more aggressively toward as a service as they've got greater confidence in moving workload and processing to the cloud. Now when is that day that they move aggressively, that's where we're all trying to figure out.

Good afternoon, and welcome to the CSRA Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Stuart Davis, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategy. Please go ahead.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aronsen. Welcome, everyone, to today's quarterly earnings conference call. Larry Prior, our CEO; and Dave Keffer, our CFO, are here to discuss our financial results, business momentum and forward outlook.Today's call is being webcast on the I
componenttext:
Thank you, Aronsen. Welcome, everyone, to today's quarterly earnings conference call. Larry Prior, our CEO; and Dave Keffer, our CFO, are here to discuss our financial results, business momentum and forward outlook.
Today's call is being webcast on the Investor Relations portion of our website, where you'll also find the earnings release and supplemental financial presentation slides that we'll be using during today's call.
The information contained in the earnings release and supplemental financial presentation is fundamentally unaudited at this point.
Turning to Slide 2 of the presentation, please note that during this call, we will make forward-looking statements that are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from anticipated results.
For a full discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please refer to our SEC filings, including our Form 10-Q from February and our Form 10-K, which we will file later this week.
In addition, the statements represent our views as of today, and subsequent events may cause our views to change. We may elect to update the forward-looking statements at some point in the future, but we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so.
Finally, as shown on Slide 3, we will discuss some non-GAAP financial measures and other metrics, which we believe provide useful information for investors. Unless specifically called out, all statements on the call reference pro forma adjusted figures.
The slide deck for today's call includes an explanation of those adjustments and other reconciliations of the figures to the most comparable GAAP measures.
At this time, it's my pleasure to turn the call over to Larry, who will begin on Slide 4.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stuart. Good afternoon, everybody. We're pleased to report another strong quarter of profitability, cash flow and business development performance. With about 6 months as a public company under our belts, merger integration is mostly behind us, an
componenttext:
Thanks, Stuart. Good afternoon, everybody. We're pleased to report another strong quarter of profitability, cash flow and business development performance. With about 6 months as a public company under our belts, merger integration is mostly behind us, and we've dramatically exceeded our cost synergy targets. We're now solidly focused on execution, and our Q4 results demonstrate the strength of our position in the market.
Since our last call, we have spent time on the road introducing the company to investors and we've gained additional research coverage, so we'll trim the commentary a bit to leave plenty of time for your questions.
As I review our performance, 3 key points standout. First, our Q4 profit and cash flow we're well ahead of our expectations, bolstering the investment thesis that we've laid out previously; second, our guidance for FY '17 demonstrates our relentless focus on efficiency to drive earnings while lingering revenue headwinds abate; and third, our long-term growth model is very much intact.
Now I'll explore each of these thoughts in a little bit more detail. First, on the quarterly results. Revenue and earnings were both up sequentially, and all of our key metrics were within or above the guidance that we gave on last call. The number one question we get from investors is, "Can you sustain your margins?" And today's results provide additional evidence that the answer is yes.
Our EBITDA margin at 17.4% leads the industry. The compatibility of our 2 legacy companies, compatibility and values like honesty and service, compatibility with our cultural affinity where the best idea wins, compatibility with a commitment to mission next-gen IT and cost control, this compatibility has allowed us to move quickly on integration and as we've come together, we've identified additional ways to operate more efficiently.
Our expanded base of fixed-price contracts incentivizes us to drive down cost continually and responsibly. Our efficiencies create a near-term revenue headwind, but are highly accretive to earnings.
During the quarter, we also posted strong bookings, which build the foundation for future revenue growth. Our book-to-bill of 1.0x for the quarter and 1.3x for the year demonstrates that we can compete fiercely in the federal IT marketplace. Almost half of the bookings in the quarter were for new business, including our $252 million 10-year award with the Security and Exchange Commission.
In addition, we generated excellent free cash flow in the quarter and stuck to our balanced capital allocation model. Free cash flow was $167 million, which is double our net income and a result of our dedication to cash collections and cash management.
We paid down significant debt, paid a quarterly dividend and repurchased our shares just as we said that we'd do when we approached the public market for the first time.
Second, on the guidance for FY '17. We will continue to carefully manage our margins to generate earnings growth. With pension income comparable to Q3 and Q4, our adjusted EBITDA range would be $886 million to $921 million and adjusted EPS would be $1.97 million to $2.10 million. This equates to year-over-year EPS growth of 4% at the midpoint and 7% at the high-end of the range. Dave  will update in just a minute the changes to the pension income that will modify these numbers.
We expect revenue of $5 billion to $5.2 billion. At the midpoint, revenue would be 2% lower than in FY '16. More than half of the revenue reduction comes from the impact of our aggressive cost reductions on cost reimbursable contracts. This cost discipline is part of our DNA and will drive earnings in cash for our shareholders, as shown by the earnings growth in our FY '17 guidance.
Within the last month, we've had a few of our new wins protested and we do not know when these will be concluded. Therefore, we've taken them out of our guidance. Our new wins over the last year have been strong, and we're confident that the book-to-bill ratios above 1 will lead to growth, which brings me to my third point on our long-term model. We are committed to 2% to 3% revenue growth and 8% to 10% EPS growth annually over the long term. Our win rates and win volumes are testament to the relevance and competitiveness of our offerings.
Our backlog is now $15.1 billion, which is about 3x annual revenue. Backlog is up 5% year-over-year and ultimately, revenue will grow in line with backlog. We have $6 billion in submitted proposals awaiting decision, and we expect to submit more than $10 billion of proposals in the first half of the year.
More broadly, our market is slowly returning to growth, and our customers are increasingly adopting next-generation IT. These trends give us further confidence in the direction we're taking the business as we aim to execute at the intersection of growing vertical markets and compelling technology offerings. In the process, you could rely on this management team to continue to take aggressive cost actions in freeing up the right resources to prudently invest in growth.
Now Dave will provide a bit more detail on the financial results and our forward outlook.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry, and good afternoon, everyone. I share Larry's view that fourth quarter results were very strong. We maintained our focus on margins and cash collections, while solidifying our team and our operations.Turning to Slide 5. I'll primarily add
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry, and good afternoon, everyone. I share Larry's view that fourth quarter results were very strong. We maintained our focus on margins and cash collections, while solidifying our team and our operations.
Turning to Slide 5. I'll primarily address pro forma and adjusted results. For prior periods, our pro forma results assumed the CSC spin and SRA merger had already occurred. And for all periods, we exclude cost directly associated with either the spin or merger transactions or the ongoing integration. We believe pro forma adjusted figures provide an important baseline for comparing the past and future performance. Our press release provides all appropriate reconciliations from pro forma adjusted results to GAAP results.
Revenue for the fourth quarter was $1.29 billion, up 1.5% sequentially and down 4.4% from $1.35 billion of pro forma revenue in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2015. The uptick in revenue compared to last quarter resulted from the normal pattern of lower leave taking in our fourth quarter than in our third.
On a pro forma basis, our Civil segment, which includes health, homeland security and other federal civilian agencies, was down 1% year-over-year. Our Defense and Intelligence segment was down 8% year-over-year. One source of this decline was our Army Logistics Modernization Program, which is transitioning to a maintenance phase after a very successful large-scale software deployment. In addition, lower material purchases on Navy contracts, the sale of our Welkin business and the wind down of Army OCO work outweighed the ramp up of valuable new intelligence programs.
Contract mix remained a key driver of profitability in Q4, as our mix continued its trend towards fixed price. As a percentage of total revenue, our contracts in the quarter were 45% fixed price, 21% time and materials and 35% cost-plus.
Keying in on the income adjustments, we incurred a GAAP noncash expense of $203 million from the annual mark-to-market process for our pension programs, which is split about 97% in cost of services and 3% in SG&A. The noncash expense was a result of the continued low interest rate environment and the return on plan assets running below our long-term assumption.
The mark-to-market remeasurement is part of our standard year-end process. We're not expecting another remeasurement gain or loss until next Q4. We also incurred merger and integration costs of $27 million in the quarter.
With that in mind, you can really see the impact of our synergy savings. Pro forma SG&A was $44 million in the quarter compared to $62 million in Q3, and we expect it to continue to decline in FY '17.
More than half of the cost synergies are in cost of services. So in total, we're already generating savings of over $150 million on an annual run rate basis.
We made tough choices quickly, which have enabled us to grow earnings, invest in growth and move forward as a team. As a result of these savings, adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $225 million, near the high-end of our guidance. Adjusted EBITDA was up 8% from the same period a year ago, as EBITDA margin increased from 15.5% to 17.4%. Fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA excludes $2 million of stock-based compensation expense and includes $28 million of net pension-related income.
Pro forma depreciation and amortization expense was $49 million, which excludes the $16 million GAAP intangibles amortization expense associated with SRAs funded contract backlog. Interest expense was $29 million in the quarter.
Late in Q4, we hedged about half of our term loan debt. So our interest expense will be approximately $6 million higher in FY '17, but we will have greater certainty and stability if interest rates rise from their historically low levels.
For comparability across periods, pro forma earnings per share are calculated assuming an effective tax rate of 39%, the company's estimated long-term rate. Pro forma adjusted diluted earnings per share for the quarter were $0.50, above the high-end of the guidance that we provided last call. EPS for the quarter was up 32% from $0.38 in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015 and up 4% from last quarter. Diluted share count for the quarter was 164 million.
The pro forma metrics for the fiscal year show the same basic patterns with the same underlying drivers as the quarterly results. Revenue was $5.2 billion, which was down 4.5% from $5.4 billion in fiscal year 2015. Adjusted EBITDA was $894 million, which was up 3.4% from $865 million in fiscal year 2015 as adjusted EBITDA margins increased from 15.9% to 17.2%. Adjusted diluted earnings per share for the fiscal year were $1.96, which was up 14% from $1.72 in fiscal year 2015.
Turning to Slide 6. We believe free cash flow should ultimately drive valuation, and it's an important metric in setting incentive compensation. Free cash flow for the quarter was $167 million or 2.1x adjusted net income, well beyond our normal model of a little better than net income as a result of sequential working capital improvements.
During the quarter, the company deployed $170 million to pay down debt, $13 million to repurchase shares and $16 million in dividends, consistent with our balanced capital deployment approach.
Day sales outstanding were 52 days as of the quarter end, an improvement of 12 days from the end of the prior fiscal year and 3 days sequentially. Our ongoing program to sell our receivables lowered DSO by about 13 days. Through this program, we're able to enhance our liquidity at a very reasonable cost because of the positive relationships that we have with our very creditworthy government customers.
As of April 1, 2016, the company had $130 million in cash and cash equivalents on the balance sheet. 
On the debt side, we had $50 million of drawn revolver, $2.8 billion of term loan debt and $151 million of capital leases at quarter end. We expect to make at least another $40 million in debt payments in the first quarter of FY '17, consistent with our term loan agreements.
Our steady cash flows and $650 million of undrawn revolver capacity provide substantial liquidity and flexibility to manage the business, pay down debt, return cash to shareholders and make accretive acquisitions.
Turning to our forward guidance on Slide 7. We project that our FY 2017 revenue will be between $5 billion and $5.2 billion, which equates to a year-over-year pro forma revenue growth rate range of minus 4% to flat, indicating progress from the rate of decline we experienced in FY '16.
We project that our adjusted EBITDA will be between $870 million and $905 million. And our adjusted diluted earnings per share will be between $1.91 and $2.04. This earnings guidance includes a reduction in projected noncash pension income of $16 million. As Larry noted, absent this change, guidance would have been $886 million to $921 million for EBITDA and $1.97 to $2.10 for EPS.
Finally, we're introducing free cash flow guidance of between $300 million and $350 million. At its midpoint, this would be slightly above our expectation for adjusted net income.
Now let me provide a little more color on some of the individual metrics, starting with revenue. We've told investors that in a typical year, we'll have 5% to 10% of our business that we need to replace. In FY '17, a few contract headwinds push us slightly above that range. In addition to the wind down of our Army Logistics Modernization Program, we'll face tough compares on a few large contracts that had outstanding performance last year and will return to more normal levels this year.
Our 3 largest movers: LMP, a loss to DHS recompete and the New York Health Insurance Exchange contract, together, decreased overall revenue by about 4%. This is part of the natural churn of our business. On top of the contract headwinds, the effective cost take out on our cost-plus contracts reduces revenue by more than a point as well.
As for tailwinds, we have had outstanding contract award activity over the past year. Recent new business awards, including those at the SEC, VA, Department of Justice and key intelligence agencies should add about 5% to our FY '17 revenue.
Two other new business awards that would have added another 1% to 2% were reversed on protest within the past month.
In total, maintaining our strong level of new business wins should get us to the midpoint of our range, and we could move higher or lower based on better win performance or unexpected delays.
On the earnings side, we're guiding to an EBITDA margin of about 17.5%, higher than our original target from the spin of 16% to 17%. We have some tough year-over-year compares for contract profitability, and interest expense hedges will cost about $6 million in FY '17. But we'll be able to sustain the excellent margins we've posted over the last 2 quarters, given higher-than-expected synergy execution and our usual strength in contract profitability.
Our guidance for the fiscal year includes a pension income forecast of $96 million based on the fourth quarter pension remeasurement. For the last half of FY '16, pension income was running at an annual rate of $112 million. Thus, the change in pension reduced our EBITDA guidance for the year by $16 million and our EPS guidance by $0.06.
To give you a picture of how the guidance will track over the fiscal year, many of the contract headwinds we've discussed are present in the first half of the fiscal year. We expect to build from there as recent and expected new business wins ramp and are reflected in the second half results.
With that, I'll turn it back to you, Larry, for some additional comments.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and it's good to see adding cash flow as a metric makes you emotional and chokes you up a bit.Before turning your questions, I want to spend a few more moments discussing our return to growth. We recognize that revenue growth is key to t
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and it's good to see adding cash flow as a metric makes you emotional and chokes you up a bit.
Before turning your questions, I want to spend a few more moments discussing our return to growth. 
We recognize that revenue growth is key to the long-term success of our business, and our recent business development results are very positive.
I'm now on Slide 8. A second half book-to-bill ratio of 1.2x in what are normally our lowest awards quarters is really great news. Looking at the quarter in detail supports a long-term growth picture. Of our $1.3 billion awards, 48% were for new works and our win rate on new work was 36%, which is well above our long-term target.
Throughout the company, we have great examples of building brilliant teams to attack the market, and I'd like to highlight 3 of them from the fourth quarter. First, as I said, we won a new 10-year $252 million contract to reshape and operate the IT infrastructure for the Securities and Exchange Commission. Project Manager, Brian Polk, led the winning team. We developed a compelling organizational change management plan and approach to mitigate the contract and migrate it from staff augmentation to fixed-price managed services. We'll be providing next-gen IT support to 6,000 users at SEC headquarters and to 11 regional offices around the country.
Second, under Leigh Palmer's and Ben Gianni's [ph] energetic leadership, we submitted our initial Greenway proposal, which is the primary recompete of our largest contract, Groundbreaker. We bid as part of the Eagle Alliance, a joint venture between CSRA and Northrop Grumman with heavy participation from our next-generation alliance partners. The massive bid submission is only the first of several submissions with an expected award in the spring or summer of calendar 2017.
Third, we won a $54 million recompete of our simulation work for the Environmental Protection Agency, with Deb Miller as the Project Manager and Proposal Lead. We're using best-in-class technologies, scientific applications and visualization technologies to develop sophisticated environmental models and simulations to provide insight into environmental issues that are just too large to replicate in the real world, like climate change. We want to be at the forefront of complex problems that span across agencies, and climate changes is one of them.
These are just a few examples of the early returns we're generating on growth investments. Still, we've not yet turned to growth, so we've decided as a company to take additional aggressive actions around business development as shown on Slide 9.
First, we continued our step-up in growth investments. As we spun out, we've been submitting about $10 billion annually in new business proposals. In the fourth quarter, we submitted about $3 billion of proposals for new awards, and we expect to accelerate that pace and reach $16 billion in new submits in FY '17.
We've also invested in differentiated technical solutions. In that area, we've just been recognized as one off 3 cloud service providers, the others being Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Azure, to meet the rigorous security standards to achieve a FedRAMP, FISMA High baseline accreditation.
Our CIO, John Dancy, deserves a lot of credit here. This is a major accomplishment in security enhancement, and it reassures our customers that CSRA is vigilant in providing highly secure government cloud services. This is one of the many signs that our strategy to become the leading partner to the U.S. Government as it transitions to next-generation IT services is on track.
Second, we changed our organizational structure and personnel. Working with the board and with Dave, I tuned up our organization to be more efficient and focused on growth. The new structure is leaner, with a heavy bias towards customer intimacy. Going from 6 groups down to 4 has created clearer lanes to pursue new work.
George Batsakis, who is the driving force behind many of the large technology driven takeaway wins at SRA, has stepped up as CSRA's Chief Growth Officer. In addition, to business development, George will oversee our alliance partnerships and our technical solutions in a unified go-to-market organization. 
Finally, we come to another first in our life as a public company with our first Annual Meeting of Stockholders of CSRA Inc. to be held on August 9, 2016. This annual meeting will be a completely virtual meeting of stockholders, which will be conducted via live webcast. As a next-gen company, we are embracing the latest technology to provide expanded access, improved communications and of course, cost savings for our stockholders and the company.
Operator, we're now ready to take some questions.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Gautam Khanna of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Gautam Khanna of Cowen and Company.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to explore 2 things. First, if you could talk about, the original 3-year guide you gave at the time of the roadshow had some fairly specific targets on the revenue CAGR and the earnings target in 2018 and I want to make -- 2019, I'm sorry. I want t
componenttext: Wanted to explore 2 things. First, if you could talk about, the original 3-year guide you gave at the time of the roadshow had some fairly specific targets on the revenue CAGR and the earnings target in 2018 and I want to make -- 2019, I'm sorry. I want to make sure that you're still committed to those, despite this year's negative organic growth?

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I was waiting for the second question. Yes, absolutely, we're committed to our long-term guidance. We -- we're really good at managing our cost structure, delivering earnings, converting to cash. So the foundation of the team is really solid. What
componenttext: Yes, so I was waiting for the second question. Yes, absolutely, we're committed to our long-term guidance. We -- we're really good at managing our cost structure, delivering earnings, converting to cash. So the foundation of the team is really solid. What we found, Gautam, is it takes us time to build that pipeline, build the number of submits and just create that forward momentum to have the new business replace any of the program erosion that Dave spoke to. We think the momentum that we've built up, the new business, is really solid and supports our long-term guidance. We wish it was happening today, but it's going to take us several hard quarters of fighting to continue to win those battles on the competitive landscape to see that growth.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just if you could also maybe provide some context around the recent recompete losses, the STRATCOM one, DHS one that Dave mentioned, was there any common threat to why you lost those? Were those surprising to you? And relatedly, on the New York
componenttext: Okay. And just if you could also maybe provide some context around the recent recompete losses, the STRATCOM one, DHS one that Dave mentioned, was there any common threat to why you lost those? Were those surprising to you? And relatedly, on the New York MIX [ph] contract, has that been extended, as you expected it would be, or what is the status there?

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first in terms of the -- setting the context, I think it's a great question. And really, fundamentally, our book-to-bill has been 1 or higher now for, I think, 5 straight quarters. And anytime we lose, especially a recompete, we really want to go to th
componenttext: So first in terms of the -- setting the context, I think it's a great question. And really, fundamentally, our book-to-bill has been 1 or higher now for, I think, 5 straight quarters. And anytime we lose, especially a recompete, we really want to go to the root cause and then see if there is any common themes. And frankly, we got some lessons learned, but they've been one-offs as opposed to anything that's systemic. Overall, our recompete win rate was about 80% for the year in terms of numbers -- I'm sorry, in terms of dollars, and I think like 96% in terms of numbers. And it's a slight downward movement, but it's not precipitous. There were 2, as Dave partially mentioned, recompete losses in the year that drove that 80% number. The first one was the SPAS program at DHS. And clearly, that was a place where the customer wanted to split the program into several smaller contracts that we were in the burst radius of his reaction to another large program, another large prime, and we all got painted as big SIs with the same brush. The awards generally went to smaller companies. And my takeaway there is, we've got to really evidence and push our capabilities around next-gen if we're going to differentiate ourselves as a big prime and really highlight the work we do with Amazon or Azure, the work we do with Big Data analytics, to not get painted with just that SI brush for enterprise work. Web SEM was another one and there, we really think the merger with SRA really would have given us a different set of cards to play with. It was an ERP job and vendor partnerships are just critical, and that's just one of the strengths that legacy CSC brings to the table. SRA just didn't have that ERP experience or quals that we now have jointly as CSRA. So I think it would have been a different outcome if we had been in play earlier.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gautam, you also mentioned the New York Health Exchange contract, just to briefly comment on that. We do still expect an extension to take our work well into the future. The nature of the decline, we mentioned, year-over-year from '16 to '17 is more relat
componenttext: Gautam, you also mentioned the New York Health Exchange contract, just to briefly comment on that. We do still expect an extension to take our work well into the future. The nature of the decline, we mentioned, year-over-year from '16 to '17 is more related to the timing of a deployment on the contract than it is to any change in our status with that customer. We have a great relationship with them, and '16's results were particularly strong as a result of a very successful deployment.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just 3 closing comments, it was an important question. The STRATCOM bid is still under protest and I can't say much about it, but we're proceeding with our protest. I am happy to report that in Q1, we did win $180 million recompete in our healthcare b
componenttext: And just 3 closing comments, it was an important question. The STRATCOM bid is still under protest and I can't say much about it, but we're proceeding with our protest. I am happy to report that in Q1, we did win $180 million recompete in our healthcare business for the congressionally directed medical research at Fort Detrick. And I know George Batsakis is absolutely focused on making every one of our recompetes blue. We have an enterprise-wide initiative that we're calling Project Indigo [ph] taking a fresh look at all of our recompetes and really doubling down on our stance going forward. So thank you for the question.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Amit Singh of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Amit Singh of Jefferies.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just staying on the revenue turnaround sort of question. You talked about next year, a large part of the headwinds being in the first half of the year. So should we expect then first quarter revenues to be sequentially down? And do you expect by the end o
componenttext: Just staying on the revenue turnaround sort of question. You talked about next year, a large part of the headwinds being in the first half of the year. So should we expect then first quarter revenues to be sequentially down? And do you expect by the end of the year when you look at revenue on a year-over-year basis you'll turn positive?

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not -- I mean, it's Dave, and I appreciate the question. We're not, at this point, going to call the quarter in which revenue growth turns positive. What we will say, consistent with your question and with our comments at the end of the call i
componenttext: Well, we're not -- I mean, it's Dave, and I appreciate the question. We're not, at this point, going to call the quarter in which revenue growth turns positive. What we will say, consistent with your question and with our comments at the end of the call is, as we think about the way the fiscal '17 quarters rollout, we do have headwinds in the first half of the year that we expect to offset with new business wins as the year progresses. We're running between 4% and 5% year-over-year declines in each of the last 4 quarters. Our guidance for the coming year at its midpoint is down 2%. So I think what you could possibly expect then is the end of the year is closer to 0% than the beginning of the year is and that's that kind of natural progression of '17. That's not to say there won't be any quarterly ups and downs throughout, but that's the general trend of it.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on synergies, is there upside from this $150 million number?
componenttext: Okay. And on synergies, is there upside from this $150 million number?

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point, cost synergies turn from being merger-related synergies, as we rollout the new organization, to being just good cost control of the company going forward. So is there additional opportunity for cost efficiency? Of course. Over time, that's
componenttext: At this point, cost synergies turn from being merger-related synergies, as we rollout the new organization, to being just good cost control of the company going forward. So is there additional opportunity for cost efficiency? Of course. Over time, that's part of the fabric of this company, is really strong cost efficiency, and the $150-plus million that we talked about on the call today is just further evidence of that strength in the company. Look, going forward, we'll continue to look for incremental efficiencies every year but certainly, don't feel like those will continue to scale on that kind of $150 million level. These will be more around the edges going forward.

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do plant this fiscal year -- this is Larry, to continue our investment in Bossier City, Louisiana with our ITC there. And we'll probably double from $350 million to north of $700 million over the course of the fiscal year to remain competitive with
componenttext: And we do plant this fiscal year -- this is Larry, to continue our investment in Bossier City, Louisiana with our ITC there. And we'll probably double from $350 million to north of $700 million over the course of the fiscal year to remain competitive with our cost of goods as well as continue to build competencies. Our Java development capability there has added a couple of customers, and we're pretty excited about continuing to invest in time and sweat equity in making that a success for sure.

Likewise, interest, which was about $30 million a month -- or $30 million a quarter, rather, over the last 2 quarters, as we mentioned on the call, would tick up only for the hedge by about $6 million, other than that, stable going forward. So each of those lines should be pretty consistent with the results we've mentioned. Tax rate, same as those that we've discussed earlier.

componenttext: So the $6 million hedge, is that an annual number? So -- I mean, you have -- you paid down a slug of debt and you've got more debt pay down coming, so is it -- does the hedge cost offset the fact that your -- have less debt outstanding or do we take $30 million and add something to it?

componenttext: You should take the $30 million and add a bit to it for the hedge, and that may be offset slightly by debt that we've paid down, but not entirely.

componenttext: 39%. Great. My other question is on all the noise last night, the new combined company, when and if it happens, will have roughly 10% federal business. I believe they don't have to divest it unless they get up to 20%, so your thoughts on that? And I mean this is the old EDS and the old CSC, so it was very competitive against each other, and I assume you still are. Do you see any change in dynamics in the market given the sort of relationship between CSC and CSRA?

headline: CSRA Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's a great question. And first, congratulations to Mike Lowry and Paul Saleh and the team over at CSC for really hitting a home run that is the true inflection point in the market. Remember the timing, Ed, their talking about closing around March of
componenttext: No, it's a great question. And first, congratulations to Mike Lowry and Paul Saleh and the team over at CSC for really hitting a home run that is the true inflection point in the market. Remember the timing, Ed, their talking about closing around March of 2017. So as a company, we've got a lot of time to think about this. For the moment, every day we team with HP and we compete with HP. So I would expect it to be business as usual for all parties as they navigate the next 9 months. I know our board is tremendously interested in it and will consider it along with all of the other strategic opportunities that will avail themselves in the market over the next year. Mike absolutely threw a big rock in the pond, spectacular moment, and we'll see how it ripples across our market.

componenttext: Bill, it's Dave. Our longer-term guidance is at or above our level of net income. That's consistent with the midpoint of our guidance for free cash for our FY '17 at $325 million. And obviously, given the nature of free cash flow and collections and payments at the tail end of fiscal year, you can see a bit of upward or downward fluctuation, and so we give that a little broader range than the other metrics, but no reason to think of that any differently than the long-term guidance we've already provided in the past.
